I'm from Sri Lanka and in our culture this was happening other way around until English invaded us with their cultural manners. In ancient Sri Lanka women were married off to one family with many brothers. In the western world, marriage is more about commitment, loyalty and never-ending love, or at least ideally, it starts that way.  Because life changes us in different ways, husband and wife may change at different rates and for different reasons, leaving the once never-ending love beat to hell and back. The truth is people are often, self-serving. As they change, they have little regard for the man or woman they once  married for life. Marriages can grow cold and stale if time and effort aren't invested continuously to keep life in the marriage. Life-long marriages are sometimes more about comfort than a reflection of never-ending love. Of course, there are wonderful exceptions, but its more the exception than the rule.  In the 3rd world, marriage is often about finances and survival for the woman and the family that might earn a bartered fee for allowing a groom to marry her. The woman often has no say. The family is simply selling her off for a return that will see the family survive in a brutal culture.

Thank you for this video, it was really interesting and I appreciate it! Even for an already open-minded person (which I would like to think that I am) there is a lot to learn about the world we live in, and the best way to learn something is to challenge things that we take for granted as right or wrong since childhood - which a video like this does...

Personally, I see nothing wrong with polygamy and polyamorous relationships in itself, as long as everybody involved are OK with it at all times and everyone respects the value of everyone else. I can also see the benefits of living in large families like this video shows, while of course being aware that no relationship is perfect and that more people probably means more challenges. However, the tradition of arranged marriages against the will of young women (and young men as well) is hard for me to accept, despite what traditions and society says, so it was nice to see an example where it turned out well for this woman. "Learning to love" is something that happens in all relationships, even those that start with a "love at first sight" moment.

It would be interesting to find out more about how the children see their families and their upbringing, and how they are handle traditions and expectations in the "changed" world of today. Any video that leaves a trail of curiosity behind is a good one for sure!

I think this co-wives arrangement was a necessity since they were a warring tribe. The men were constantly being killed in warfare and life expectancy of children was low with a high mortality rate. Disease, sickness and infection killed many of all ages. Which all maintained a sustainable population balance.
With the introduction of modern medicine and diplomacy replacing battle to solve issues the population is no longer kept in check. Due to these changes the new generations are changing their ways in response to the increasing population density. Customs and traditions will be a response to the dwindling environment.
So, this was right for them under historic conditions.

@Craven Â @CravenÂ  You said: "Therfore, it is wrong, regardless of anyone's 'opinion'". But do you realize there is subjective opinion in there that presumes that harming children is wrong? The thing is, science cannot tell us if something is right or wrong. We may be able to establish that sexual abuse of children harms them. But what or who determines that harming children or, anyone for that matter, is right or wrong? I would certainly agree, but as we are aware not everybody thinks so.

The nazi's for example were all agreed that it is right to harm others for the greater good of preserving the superior man and ridding the world of genetically inferior people. I'm sure we would both agree that this is wrong. But why? It's just the opinion of that group of people versus the opinion of our group of people that this is wrong. Science can measure the effects, but can't tell you which group is morally right and which is morally wrong.

So it is actually the contrary...it's not that I don't think we can't establish what is truly right and wrong. I think that there must be a moral source beyond (differing) subjective human opinions. And I believe that God, as our creator, is that source. Only so is there a source of morality that supersedes opinion, desires and feelings. As F. Dostoevsky said... "Without God everything is permissable". If mankind were random bags of DNA that happend by chance, ofcourse...there would be no one setting up the boundaries beyond mankind's own opinions, which widely differ.

So my point was just...that Truth IS established by a objective source. And thus also the truth of the purpose for mankind in regards to the union of them in a marriage. As such I do not believe polygamy or or other forms of such union between humans is right.

@Shanevan Duinkerk I disagree with where your comment is going because you make it sound like there's absolutely no way of establishing what's truly right and wrong. There are definitely plenty of moral gray areas but there are definitely things that can be proven to be wrong, beyond opinion. Things based in scientific fact, such as sexual abuse of children. Children cannot consent, and that is a fact. It will traumatize them for the rest of their lives, one way or another, and that is a fact. Therefore, it is wrong, regardless of anyone's "opinion."

Are we really all that different? You meet a man, marry and start having kids. Marriage breaks down but he continues to support you and your children but now has wife number two. As he has shared custody of the kids with you, wife #2 will be looking after kids from her first marriage, her kids from this new marriage, and your kids when they have visitation. Now you marry again and have more kids, but are also looking after kids from your new husband's first marriage. It's a lot of work, and you do it alone. And this can keep going so long as these men are able to generate the income to support all these families.
The key difference between what I just described and what I see here is that instead of some bitter split and fighting over resources between first wife family unit and husband#2/second wife family unit is that instead there is a cultural tradition and attitude that all these wives should get along and help each other out. So when you are home on maternity leave (or a stay at home parent with a new child) you are not at home alone dealing with all that work, you have an extended family unit of other wives as well all sharing the work and helping out. That and when new wives are added to the equation you don't have a bleeding of resources out to pay for divorce lawyers. The communal wealth of this group remains in the group.

Each wife has her own house separate from the others. Unlike the family home she grew up in this is hers, and she is left for the most part head of that house. And there are the shared resources of an extended community looking out for her needs.

As a mother to both a girl and a boy (and happily married for 15 years) I would like to add my little 2 cents. I don't see anything wrong with the concept of polygamy and having a family-village style life. The only thing that I see so clearly overlook in all the comments (but simply not discussed in the video) is that apart from Stephanie, none of these girls had a choice. They were forced, at a very young age, to marry off someone both older than themselves and not of their choosing. Choice does matter, as do age. A child is a child, no matter the culture. Girls this young often die in childbirth, even more so far removed from modern medicine. Just because it is not mentioned in the video doesn't make it okay. Girls should not be traded for cows and should not be married off before they are physically able to have both sexual encounters and carry a pregnancy. Not traditions are good and worth preserving. So: yes to the culture, no to the trade and exploitation of young girls. And for the record, my husband and his family are African and do not condone this.

WOW these comments...."She should have 3 husbands as well"....it's not that easy people. It's not about what's "fair" but rather tradition, family structure/hierarchy and above all else HOW YOU CAN PROVIDE AND BUILD FOR YOUR FAMILY. A man could not have 3 wives if he weren't able to support and take care of them as a family unit. Flipping it and crying for the wife to have 3 husbands (which some tribes do, do your homework) but it's primarily about tradition and what you can provide for. In tribes that are patriarchal, yes, they look to the man to provide for them and it is a luxury to have multiple wives, but don't think for a second that it is "easy" the man has to work 3X as hard.

Even though I don't agree with the practice, I can sort of understand the acceptance of multiple wives. Not so much the no choice part. But, think about it this way. Here in "Western" culture, we have a problem with men staying faithful. We have a problem with men trying to forcibly take what they want whenever they want.  This culture sort of forces the man to be a man. It allows him to have as many choices in women as he wants, visit whichever one/all he chooses. But! He has to provide them with shelter, land, protection and a means for food. I know wealthy women who settle for much worse. (look at Oprah and Stedman's relationship) My aunt in Jersey had the same situation for years. Many of them KNOW who their spouse is cheating with and don't care. My grandfather who was born in Arkansas moved his family and his mistress (and kids) up here to Cleveland Ohio. He had a full set of 8 kids with the mistress as well as the 9 he had with my grandmother. The kids played together and lives around the corner from each other and no one knew anything until my grandfather died. Again, I'm not saying that I agree with it, but who am I to judge them because it's not something I would do. Just saying.

I find it sadly curious that people keep saying"there's no jealousy because there's no real love". Love isn't jealous. Even in the Christian definition of love, there is not jealousy.

"Love is patient, love is kind. It does not envy, it does not boast, it is not proud. It is not rude, it is not self-seeking, it is not easily angered, it keeps no record of wrongs."

Love, real love, does not breed jealousy. Greed does. Insecurity does. Infatuation does. But not love.

Love is respect. Love is not simply 'romance' but a meeting of minds with common ground and a willingness to learn and compromise.

It's sad that the woman in this video had to come to love through a trial of being frightened and alone and unable to make choices for herself, and she should definitely have been allowed to make those choices for herself. But it should be said that there is something to be joyful about, in knowing that she believes that she has had a happy life. That, by HER definition of it, not ours, she has found love, not just with her husband but with his other wives, as well.

Is this true for all polygamous marriages? Of course not.

Is this true for all Masai marriages? Of course not.

But we belittle this amazing woman by judging what she says and the life that she leads, by enforcing upon her our definition of 'love'.

PSA to all these commenters: If something about a culture makes you uncomfortable, that's your problem - not theirs. Yes there are things about Massai culture that are odd to us westerners: polygamy, young brides, "primal" living.

But Yayai wasn't asking for rescue or help. She wasn't miserable. She didn't seem concerned for her children. She doesn't want to change her situation it seems. She seems happy and proud of her culture and way of life. And WE need to respect that.

It doesn't matter AT ALL if you understand it, approve of it, like it, hate it, or whatever. And it's not your place to "fix" them. It's not your place to provide them with your "morals". It's not okay to shove your western ideas, technogical advancements, and modern life on another culture. Humans are incredibly diverse and nuanced creatures. Your culture and language affect what you think and how you CAN think.

We believe in one wife per marriage, at least one at a time! Our divorce rates are high in United States. In Masai culture, the husband who tires of his wife as she ages just brings home another one, but still keeps the first wife, or two. Now that's marital security! Most divorced women in US end up poorer than the man after a divorce, and struggle as single parents, and have to depend on the child support that they don't always get. She may remarry and her new husband may mistreat her children with her first husband. That won't happen in Masai culture. And the co-wives always have each to share in childcare and chores. So maybe the Masai have the right idea, at least for their rural and economic lifestyle.

I'm going to start off saying that I'm neither a proponent of a monogamous marriage nor of a polygamous marriage. From what I see is that Yayai has found a way to be happy in a situation she had no control over. Her life was very isolating and lonely with just her husband, whom she did not like. To have a "co-wife" meant having a friend who had to go through what you went through. That you're not alone in misery. It appears that Maasai women find comfort in having friends that cannot leave, along with dedicating their lives to their children and grandchildren. They cannot understand monogamous marriages because that's not how things are, (or were) it's more about finding a way to be happy. To find your own slither of freedom in a situation you have no control over. Of course she doesn't mind her husband being with another woman, she doesn't even like him. (E.g. imagine that one person that's interested in you. However, you don't reciprocate, so if they go after someone else it's a relief.) That's probably how she feels, having intercourse with someone you dislike isn't fun. You just want the interaction to end or better yet, be directed at someone else. That's how she lives, that's her normal.

I see many people in the comments saying this is wrong or wtv and I just wonder, why do we in the west always have to see things in a dichotomy - black or white, right or wrong? Specially in a situation where the information we are getting is through a white westerner lens, even the way things are translated affects the way we perceive it. There are many differences in the way Western society and this tribe work, ancient differences that made us have different thought processes and ideals. I understand that many things in this video might cause outrage and feel unfair, but we don't know the history and specially how the tribes practices where affected by the western world, the invasions of white ppl in Africa and many other things that would have to be carefully evaluated by historians and anthropologists.
I once read a book "Spirit of intimacy" by Sobonfu SomÃ© that describes the philosophies and practices of a tribe in the Burkina Faso area and she's from a tribe and later in life lived in the west, so she is better suited to transmit the information accurately so we can understand. althought it's distant from Tanzania, one insight I took from that book is that even tribes that "stick to their traditions" get affected by the poisonous colonizer's thought and practices. and many tribes' practices that once had purer meanings, rooted in community and the well being of everyone where corrupted by materialistic thought and such. for example, something that was later known as the dowry in that tribe, once had a purpose of sharing something with the whole community, had spiritual implications, ... The arranged marriage too, has a link to the tribe's spirituality and practices.Â 
it's VERY easy to come and critique these tribes. but I think it's really untasteful especially with the "this is wrong!!" stance. It's the way ppl are living and we have to respect it. and honestly, the western viewpoint on this is highly questionable.

ALSO, in Cheikh Anta Diop's book "civilization or barbarism" he mentions the concept of polygamy in the sense that the husband has many wives, and that was because it made sense for the survival and thriving of the whole community, since there were many more women than man. People shared, and maybe with the passing of years the reasons for the man-with-many-wives but no wife-with-multiple-husband were lost but instead of just judging we should think of the reasons behind things and often the original reasons were very plausible and the intentions were distorted with time and with the colonizers perspective of individualism and the persistent anti-blackness that affects these narratives.

I would like to point out that this was not the original way of the Maasai culture. In precolonial times it was a polyandrous community. Romance was not synonymous to relationships.

Marriage was a socioeconomic and political tool to empower the family unit. Women were also involved in rejecting or choosing a marriage partner as it would affect her standing in society. Extra martial relationships were allowed, the only requirement was that one was expected to choose a casual partner in the same age group as their spouse. The wives were responsible to vet out potential co-wives. In a way the whole marriage was like a business partnership where people were chosen based on their strengths and compatibility. Women brought in wealth and homestead management whereas the men provided security and acted as liaisons for the family unit.

With the invasion of the explorers and colonialists. This mindset shifted to a more oppressive approach towards the female's control over such affairs. Family units that went against the patriarchy were shunned by others who did not want to jeopardize the new founded relationship with the westerners. With time the Maasai women lost their independence.

But times have changed and as mentioned the Maasai women have slowly gained back the control over the homestead.

Yayai grew up in a time where male children were the only ones privy to an education and access to the outside world hence gained opportunities to finances and political influence.

In today's society the girls get equal opportunity and run most of the tourist programs and ranch management while the men join wildlife protective programs and political groups to protect their indigenous culture. In a sense their heading back to their original roots where women run the homestead and the man protects the integrity of the homestead.

Ps. This information is widely taught in our history classes and at heritage locations in Kenya and Tanzania. Make a point of popping to get a clear picture. In many communities the African concept of gender had no inferior or superior tags, the west just assumed we did and enforced the ideology on us.

I'm from peru, and even though we dont practice polygamy we do live in  extended family households, similar to the "boma", most of my aunt live in there with their husband and childents, so when my mom was working we didn't have a babysitter, my aunts would just keep an eye on us along their children, we were a ton of ppl, and my cousins were also my friends and even kinda like my  siblings, my aunts were like second moms and the place was never quite. Living with a lot of ppl has its ups and downs, for instance there were no secrets or privacy, our economy wasn't that good, and when we were kids our older cousin was a bully (to all the little children in the house). When we came to USA (utah) the economy got better, much better, there was privacy, and a lot of silence since everyone was working and nobody was around, I could be in the phone all day if I wanted to (before I couldn't bc my auts wouldn't let me), if I bought something I didn't had to share my food (there were too many people in the house, so If u had something u have to shared it with everyone) and could eat all I wanted since junk food is cheap...idk which is better, but at least back then it was so noisy and there were so many ppl that u didn't really had the time or energy to be depressed

@Baroness von Rat I see what you mean. And your situation surrounding Swedish meatballs and Semla(sounds delicious btw) doesn't sound petty to me. I think food is part of what makes a certain place "home" if that makes any sense. Sitting down and eating a local meal can be a very warm experience. Especially if you have childhood memories of eating that food. Maybe even your family making that food. If the media is falsely telling you that the food is not a part of your home, it can be a form of psychological warfare in my opinion.

As a Filipino-American, I'm well aware that everything has "origins" from somewhere else. Both the U.S. and the Philippines are colonial nations with colonial cultures. We are young countries compared to other parts of the world. Both countries are basically an amalgamation of different ideas from different places. Its a lot more obvious in colonial countries that things "come from somewhere else". But isn't that literally every country ever? Japan has a ton of Confucian and Buddhist culture that originates from ancient China, Korea, and India. But does that make Japanese culture NOT Japanese culture? No. Because they made it their own. Its called "integration". Every culture can integrate things from outside, and make it uniquely a part of their own culture.

This should be pretty obvious. But as you know, the media will spin it as a narrative of things being stolen from other countries. Its more of a psychological trick than anything. It preys off of peoples' deeply rooted shame. Shame that is likely originating from some personal aspect of their lives, but is being scapegoated onto their culture and even race.

Yayai and the Maasai people (as with other polygamous cultures) seem to show a less complicated look at love and marriage... to a point. While it seems that there is less drama on the part of the co-wives who welcome and accept each others' presence in the boma, how would it be if the women wanted to have another lover/husband other than the ones they were arranged to be with. So, Maasai women do not grow up with thoughts of jealousy, what about Maasai men?
While she pointed out that today's younger generation are no longer forced to be in arranged marriages, it seems that Maasai women are still not "allowed" to have more than one husband. How would this narrative change if a married Maasai woman found another man she likes or loves? Is polygamy okay but not polyamory?

I would love to hear more and learn more about this fascinating way of love and marriage. Kudos to Eva!

@daenerys max it is something biological! People try to talk about things they know nothing of. Lions, kangaroos, wolves and many other animals (including primates) indulge in polygamy. You've already started.  By simply viewing this video and asking yourself that question, you began the journey.  Always remember to look at all sides of an issue.  There is no "right" and there is no "wrong" -- everything is perspective.  I highly recommend reading into Franz Boas' concept of cultural relativism.  He is the father of American Anthropology, and the further I got into my PhD in Anthropology, the more I got from his concept.  It really is critical!
